title: 113_hr5094
content: AUTHORITY TO RECOUP BONUSES OR AWARDS PAID TO EMPLOYEES OF DEPARTMENT OF VETERANS AFFAIRS. The Department of Veterans Affairs has the authority to recoup bonuses or awards paid to employees by issuing an order for repayment if deemed appropriate by the Secretary. The employee must be given notice and an opportunity for a hearing before the decision is final. The Department of Veterans Affairs has the authority to recoup bonuses or awards paid to employees by issuing an order for repayment. The decision made by an employee pursuant to subsection (a) is final and cannot be reviewed by any other agency or court. Section 714 of title 38, United States Code allows the Department of Veterans Affairs to recoup bonuses or awards paid to employees. The provision applies to awards or bonuses paid before, on, or after the enactment of the Act. Additionally, the Act does not modify the certification issued by the Office of Personnel Management and the Office of Management and Budget regarding the performance appraisal system of the Senior Executive Service of the Department of Veterans Affairs. Section 8127 of title 38, United States Code is amended to include limitations on subcontracting for small business concerns owned and controlled by veterans with service-connected disabilities. The requirements of section 46 of the Small Business Act apply to these small businesses, including subcontractors. The amended Section 8127 of title 38, United States Code imposes subcontracting limitations for small businesses owned by veterans with service-connected disabilities. Before awarding a contract, the Secretary must obtain a certification from the offeror to comply with the requirements. If a small business awarded a contract does not act in good faith, the Secretary may take action. The Director of Small and Disadvantaged Business Utilization and the Chief Acquisition Officer will jointly monitor compliance with subcontracting limitations for small businesses owned by veterans with service-connected disabilities. Violations will be referred to the Inspector General for action. The Director of Small and Disadvantaged Business Utilization and the Chief Acquisition Officer will jointly refer violations of subcontracting limitations for small businesses owned by veterans with service-connected disabilities to the Inspector General for action. The Inspector General will submit an annual report to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs detailing the number of violations received and their dispositions, including any small business concerns suspended or debarred from Federal contracting or referred for prosecution. This provision will apply to contracts entered into after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 3. REVIEW OF LISTS OF FORMER PRISONERS OF WAR. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will review VA and DOD lists of prisoners of war for any discrepancies. The Inspector General will review the process for determining a veteran's status as a former POW. A report on the VA POW list, including discrepancies and veterans listed, must be submitted to Congress within 180 days. The VA Secretary will review lists of prisoners of war for discrepancies, including how determinations were made for veterans not on both lists. Definitions for DOD and VA POW lists are provided. SEC. 4. LIMITATION ON EXPANSION OF DIALYSIS PILOT PROGRAM. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is restricted from expanding the dialysis pilot program or creating new dialysis capability in facilities other than initial ones until certain conditions are met, including a two-year implementation at initial facilities, independent analysis, and submission of a report to Congress. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is required to consider various factors, including cost, access to care, quality of care, and Veteran satisfaction when evaluating the dialysis pilot program. Additionally, existing dialysis resources within the Department should be fully utilized to improve veterans' access to care and reduce travel time. The term "dialysis pilot program" refers to a demonstration program established by the Secretary in 2009. The Secretary established a dialysis pilot program in 2009 to provide care at VA outpatient facilities. The bill aims to allow the VA to recoup bonuses paid to employees.
